makers.displaydate: 1905–1984; born Crandon, WI; died East Cornwall, CT; active Cornwall and New York, NY
makers.displaymaker: Armin Landeck, 1905–1984; born Crandon, WI; died East Cornwall, CT; active Cornwall and New York, NY

texts.textentryhtml: Richard and Lois Reinis; gifted to Princeton University Art Museum, 2022.

Landeck moved from the Midwest to enroll at Columbia University, where he earned a degree in architecture and developed a passion for printmaking. His keen interest in different building styles, and his experience of his new city life are evident in this nocturnal scene, which emphasizes a figure’s isolation through strong contrasts of light and shadow. Utilizing drypoint technique, Landeck scraped lines with an etching needle directly onto the surface of a metal plate. When the plate was inked, both the carved lines and the resulting metal residue, the burr, transferred an intricate web of marks onto the sheet of paper, creating the enveloping darkness at the right of the image. In comparison to Lynn Thomas Morgan’s quiet view of New York City above, Landeck’s print provides a lower vantage point, drawing the viewer into a neighborhood.

displaymaker: Armin Landeck, 1905–1984; born Crandon, WI; died East Cornwall, CT; active Cornwall and New York, NY
